pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the basics of discrete fair division in mathlib. We include the definitions of allocations, valuations, properties of valuations, and the following notions : Envy-Freeness (EF), Envy-Freeness upto 1 good (EF1), and envy freeness upto any good (EFX). We also include the various implications between these notions.

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

### PR summary [c6e9942aa5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16253/commits/c6e9942aa5d9114ce83612c0f17610e7561034b6)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.GameTheory.FairDivision.Discrete.Basic`|670|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Alloc`
`+ EF`
`+ EF1`
`+ EF1_agents`
`+ EFX`
`+ EFX_agents`
`+ EFX_implies_EF1`
`+ EF_agents`
`+ EF_implies_EF1`
`+ EF_implies_EFX`
`+ Val`
`+ additive`
`+ allocate`
`+ complete`
`+ empty_alloc_is_EF`
`+ isEmpty`
`+ isEmptyAlloc`
`+ unAllocated`
`+ valSingle`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I think this should be
```
abbrev Val := Agents → OrderBotHom Goods ℝ≥0
```
where `OrderBotHom` doesn't currently exist.

Two things:
1. What is `OrderBotHom`?
2. The way I have stated these definitions is basically how researchers in this field would understand these valuation functions. A lot of arguments use these individual properties both implicitly and explicitly.

> I think this should be
> ```
> abbrev Val := Agents → OrderBotHom Goods ℝ≥0
> ```
> where `OrderBotHom` doesn't currently exist.

A third point: One can define additional properties on these valuation functions like submodularity, additivity, subadditivity etc.

> What is OrderBotHom?

`structure OrderBotHom (A B) extends OrderHom A B, BotHom A B` or similar

> One can define additional properties on these valuation functions like submodularity, additivity, subadditivity etc.

This is perhaps an argument for writing your theorem assuming `[OrderHomClass F Goods ℝ≥0] [BotHomClass F Goods ℝ≥0]`, so that you can then apply it with `abbrev Val := Agents → F`, and still use it on other types of valuation.
This is the same as `alloc.assign = ⊥`, which saves you a definition. You could quite reasonably even implement a `Bot Alloc` instance to make this `alloc = ⊥`.
This is good evidence that `Agents` and `Goods` should be explicit arguments to `alloc`.

pullRequest.title: feat: Basics of Discrete Fair Division in Mathlib
